Award.AwardTitle: Research on the Development of Computational and Systems Thinking in Middle School Students through Explorations of Complex Earth Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computing has been a central tool in the development of modern understanding in many fields of science, technology, engineering and math (STEM). Skills such as modeling, data visualization, and computational thinking are all necessary for building a diverse scientific workforce that will secure a strong future for the United States. As a result, NSF's STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to integrate the use of computational approaches in K-12 STEM teaching and learning. TERC, Inc., in collaboration with Northeastern University and the cambridge, Newton, and Lowell, Massachusetts Public School Districts, will develop and study an education program that integrates computing into middle school Earth systems science by interweaving computational skills development into science game design and science content learning. The project aims to develop skills among diverse groups of young people in two crucial fields central to national interest and safety. More importantly, the project will bring these two fields together to create a learning environment in which young people learn thinking from a systems perspective, essential to solving complex scientific problems. The project will contribute to practical models for developing science content learning and computer skills, creating positive attitudes toward science, and broadening participation in the sciences among middle school students in diverse settings.

The Building Systems from Scratch project will develop, implement, and study an innovative intervention that integrates computing into an 8-week Earth systems curriculum and supporting resources. The program will include: a) a standards-aligned curriculum focused on systems thinking practices, b) a 52-hour hybrid online/face-to-face teacher professional development workshop with supporting materials, c) a teacher leader guide for sustainable implementation of the program, and d) a website to support program materials, activities, and communication. Specifically, as students build their own science content games, they will engage in computational practices such as modeling, abstraction, management of complexity, and creative design, as well as iterative testing and debugging. The project seeks to understand how and what young people learn when they engage in interdisciplinary learning in technology-rich environments. It further seeks to understand how curricular structural supports influence student learning and self-efficacy. The project will address specific needs of middle school students and teachers with regard to relevant disciplinary content, science practices, and computation as specified in Next Generation Science Standards and Computer Science Standards. The project will be working with fifteen 8th grade teachers in three Massachusetts school districts across three years, reaching approximately 1,840 8th grade students, over half of whom are from groups underrepresented in STEM and computer science fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research on the Development of Computational and Systems Thinking in Middle School Students through Explorations of Complex Earth Systems

Designing computer games is a rich and creative activity that supports learning in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM).  It is becoming popular in formal and informal learning settings.  Part of the success of game design is participants' willing engagement in creating works of their own choice and vision. This approach to teaching and learning gives students more authority by making them more than consumers of already known information or inquirers into already understood phenomena, as is typical in many STEM classes. There is a need to integrate computing into science instruction to develop students' computational thinking practices (CTP).  However, since science teachers often do not have experience with CTP themselves, they need to understand how to re-structure learning in the classroom for successful integration.

In this project, we sought to develop and test an innovative 8th grade curriculum that integrated the disciplinary practices of climate change science, game design, and computing. We researched how students drew on these disciplines while designing and creating a computer game in Scratch, a block-based programming language, that taught others about a climate change topic of their choice. We also studied what strategies supported teachers to adapt and implement an integrated curriculum that included an unfamiliar computing tool.

Over four years, the curriculum was implemented in three school districts in two states, serving a total of 18 eighth-grade teachers and 2,140 students. We gave 16 conference presentations and published 10 studies on student learning, teacher implementation and curriculum design. Our work has shown how:

  • Game design can support students learning in a discipline (climate science) and at the same time increase students' skills in using CTP, as well as significantly increase student self-efficacy
  • Relying on distributed expertise among students can support technology integration in science classrooms
  • The design and implementation of a fully integrated curriculum can support students' interdisciplinary learning
  • Assessment of how computational thinking practices develop over time can be partially automated by logging students' game construction moves.

We created instructional materials and accompanying teacher guide as well as a guide for educator professional learning that included ideas about changing educators' relationships to disciplines, tools, and learners, for example, identifying principles for supporting participatory pedagogy. These, together with a sample of student-created games and information about our research, are available on our newly designed website at www.terc.edu/buildingsystems.
